verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: No major differences. Introductory formula common in Numbers.

verses.text: Speak to the Israelites and take from them a staff from each father's house, twelve staffs from all their leaders, according to their fathers' houses. Write each man’s name on his staff.
verses.comment: Maintains singular 'staff' per leader; clear on Israelite tribal structure.

verses.text: And write Aaron’s name on the staff of Levi, because there must be one staff for the head of each father's house.
verses.comment: Specifies Aaron for Levi; keeps 'father's house' terminology.

verses.text: Place them in the tent of meeting before the testimony, where I meet with you.
verses.comment: ‘Testimony’ refers to the Ark; 'tent of meeting' is more modern than 'tabernacle.'

verses.text: The staff of the man whom I choose will sprout, and I will put an end to the complaints of the Israelites against you.
verses.comment: Simplifies 'cease from me the murmurings'; keeps direct speech.

verses.text: So Moses spoke to the Israelites, and all their leaders gave him staffs, one for each leader, twelve staffs in all. And the staff of Aaron was among their staffs.
verses.comment: Retains repetition to preserve original style and clarity.

verses.text: Moses placed the staffs before the LORD in the tent of the testimony.
verses.comment: ‘Tent of testimony’ interchangeably used with 'tent of meeting.'

verses.text: The next day, when Moses went into the tent of the testimony, the staff of Aaron for the house of Levi had sprouted. It had budded, blossomed flowers, and produced almonds.
verses.comment: Keeps detail of buds, blossoms, and almonds true to Hebrew text.

verses.text: Then Moses brought out all the staffs from before the LORD to all the Israelites. They saw them, and each man took his own staff.
verses.comment: Clear sequencing for modern readers; maintains directness.

verses.text: But the LORD said to Moses, 'Put Aaron’s staff back before the testimony, to be kept as a sign against the rebellious, so their complaints against Me may cease, and they may not die.'
verses.comment: Retains 'rebellious' and ‘complaints’; directly following the original word order.

verses.text: Moses did just as the LORD commanded him; he did so.
verses.comment: Repetition for emphasis is retained, as in the original Hebrew.

verses.text: The Israelites said to Moses, 'Surely we will die, we are lost, everyone who comes near the LORD's tabernacle will die. Are we all to perish?'
verses.comment: Condenses multiple exclamations into one sentence for clarity but retains sense of panic.

verses.text: Anyone who approaches the LORD's tabernacle will die. Will we all perish?
verses.comment: Maintains repetition for dramatic effect, as present in the Hebrew.
